izzy.classification.GenericModel¶

class izzy.classification.GenericModel[source]¶

GenericModel class. Note that this is an abstract class.

classify(x, classes=None, threshold=None)[source]¶

Evaluate at x and then classify

If the problem is binomial, threshold is used to perform classification. Otherwise, the class with greatest probability is chosen.

See classify()

Parameters

  • x (ArrayLike) – Independent variables

  • classes (ArrayLike) – Class labels (Default: numbers from 0 to number classes - 1)

  • threshold (float) – Decision boundary cutoff (Default: 0.5)

Returns

Predicted classes of each observation

Return type

numpy.ndarray

log_likelihood(x, y, normalize=True)[source]¶

Computes the log-likelihood

Mathematically, for a sample \(i\), we compute the likelihood \(L_i = p_i^{y_i} (1-p_i)^{1-y_i}.\) Here, we compute \(p\) as the predicted probability and \(y\) as the true outcome.

We can choose to normalize by the number of samples to get the average log likelihood per sample.

The procedure is to use x to get the predicted probabilities, and then compute \(L_i\) above.

Note that the log likelihood depends on the specific variables in the model, i.e., cross-comparison of models is with different features is technically incorrect.

Parameters

  • x (ArrayLike) – Independent variable(s)

  • y (ArrayLike) – Dependent variable(s)

  • normalize (bool) – Should we normalize by the number of samples? (Default: True)

Returns

log likelihood

Return type

float

log_loss(x, y)[source]¶

Compute the log loss. This is the negative log likelihood. See log_likelihood()

Parameters

  • x (ArrayLike) – Independent variable(s)

  • y (ArrayLike) – Dependent variable(s)

standard_errors(x, y, mode='R')[source]¶

Computes the standard errors of parameters

\[standard errors = \sqrt{diag(covariance matrix)}\]
Parameters

  • x (ArrayLike) – Independent variable(s)

  • y (ArrayLike) – Dependent variable(s)

  • mode (str) – See mode in variance_covariance_matrix()

Returns

standard errors

Return type

numpy.ndarray

variance_covariance_matrix(x, y, mode='R')[source]¶

Computes the variance-covariance matrix

The covariance matrix can be calculated in two ways.

  1. statsmodels method, which calculates the inverse of the Fisher information matrix (FIM). Note that FIM is the negative Hessian, which is equal to the second derivative of the loss function evaluated at the maximum likelihood estimate.

  2. R method, which calculates the QR decomposition of \(x\sqrt{d}\). Here, \(d\) indicates \(y_{pred} (1 - y_{pred})\). If there are \(n\) features, then the Householder reflector \(h\) from QR provides the Cholesky matrix \(h[:n, :n]\). The inverse of this matrix gives us the covariance. This method, which relies on LAPACK, is significantly more efficient than (1).

https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/68080/basic-question-about-fisher-information-matrix-and-relationship-to-hessian-and-s https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/224302/how-does-r-function-summary-glm-calculate-the-covariance-matrix-for-glm-model/407734#407734

Parameters

  • x (ArrayLike) – Independent variable(s)

  • y (ArrayLike) – Dependent variable(s)

  • mode (str) – ‘statsmodels’ for covariance computed from the Hessian or ‘R’ for the Cholesky method (Default: ‘R’)

Returns

variance-covariance matrix

Return type

numpy.ndarray
